sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a circular loop
message_1: A circular loop of radius 10 cm carries a current of 2 A. Calculate the magnetic field at a point on its axis 5 cm from the center of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point on the axis of a circular loop, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where:
B is the magnetic field
μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A)
I is the current in the loop
R is the radius of the loop
x is the distance from the center of the loop to the point on the axis

Given:
I = 2 A
R = 10 cm = 0.1 m
x = 5 cm = 0.05 m

Now, we can plug in the values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * (0.1 m)²) / (2 * ((0.1 m)² + (0.05 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.01 m²) / (2 * (0.01 m² + 0.0025 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-9) Tm) / (2 * (0.0125 m²)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-9) Tm) / (2 * 0.0125^(3/2) m^(3/2))

B ≈ 1.60 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field at a point on the axis 5 cm from the center of the loop is approximately 1.60 × 10^(-5) Tesla.
